Overview

Aim

To create a functional, accessible kitchen garden that will allow people of all abilities, physicalities and ages to enjoy growing edible plants.

Date

18.08.21

Location

West Yorkshire

Client

CC

Status

To be implemented

Domain

Land/nature stewardship

Principles

Framework

GoSADIM:

Goal setting, Survey, Analysis, Decision Making, Implementation, Manage
Then the additional steps of Evaluate & Tweak

By Graham Burnett at Spiral Seed  

Tools

Basemap, PASTE, DAFOR, sector analysis, overlays

Resources/support

Miro, Suncalc.org, Pinterest, Google Earth, 

Context/Scope of design

This a design about creating a functional and accessible kitchen garden to be used by a community for learning, connecting with nature, socialising and having fun

The client wanted to install a kitchen garden that would be the focus for activities for community groups.

This was the extent of the brief.  The client left it to myself and the company I was working with to create a garden that we could develop into a sustainable business.

I decided to use this opportunity to create my dream kitchen garden, and one that would be accessible to as many people as possible. I decided to use materials that had the least ecological impact and to include elements that would benefit all aspects of the environment, where possible.

The site for the kitchen garden is within a larger area designated for a bigger community gardens project. This in turn is on a very large site. There are many logistical details that need to be addressed, but these are not in the remit of this design

 

Goal articulation

I would like to create a garden that;

  • produces a wide variety of fruit and vegetables
  • increases biodiversity
  • provides opportunities for people can come to learn and connect with nature/the growing process
  • is accessible for everyone and can engage a diverse range of people
  • is not only sustainable but also regenerative
  • strengthens the local community and is shaped by the local community
  • looks beautiful, to inspire and engage
  • uses environmentally friendly and organic methods - reducing waste, recycling/reusing. free from pesticides, herbicides, no peat, no dig, less fossil fuels (hand tools rather than power tools)
  • uses local resources, especially waste from on site, e.g. woodchip, leaves and grass clippings

I created a mood board on Pinterest

Survey

You can see all my survey information on this Miro board.

I have created a photo map of the site..

Geographical location

Site systems and elements

To identify what was already on the site I did the following.

I created a base map using Google Earth

I used the PASTE acronym to help me categorise what was on the site

I then used the DAFOR acronym to indicate the frequency of each plant

 

Sector Analysis

Due to time constraints, I have only done a very basic sector analysis. I have not made observations myself, but have used general data available on the internet. This is sufficient for the project. 

Shade will not affect the design per se, but will influence how crops are grown, but that is not within the remit of this design. 

The greenhouse to the east of the raised bed area will cast some shade at times.

The Horse Chestnut to the South of the raised bed area will also cast some shade at times.

The trees to the west, north and east of the site will provide a windbreak, as will the walls that surround the whole site. Again, this is only really relevant to the growing of crops.

The site is fairly exposed, especially as a large number of very tall conifers have recently been cut down. These used to surround the kitchen garden site. further developments of the site, such as the creation of a forest garden, may well provide protection. 

 

Limiting factors


Physical limiting factors
There is no water catchment at present.
The irrigation system is limited to one tap, which is by the wall to the east. This is a long way from where the kitchen garden has been cited.
Deer have access to the site via the car park entrance.
Squirrels, rabbits and pigeons are likely to damage crops
There are several areas that may be problematic for accessibility for those using wheelchairs/other mobility aids - different levels, trip hazards, broken paths etc.

Non - physical limiting factors
There are many unknowns - funding, community engagement logistics, local residents' reactions, communication systems.

There are many separate parties involved. We do not know each other very well, and the communication system is long-winded. Communication is disjointed, objectives are unclear etc.

We do not own the land.

We do not know if the design will be implemented.

At present, we do not have a tenure agreement.

No local people have been involved in this project as yet.

Resources


Woodchip and  leaves from the site

Greenhouse

We may have workers from CC, in the form of young people on a training programme

ST infrastructure - accounts, email system, established business w contacts etc.

Knowledge and skills - myself and Killian have excellent skills in  growing, organisation, teaching and planning

ST will be part of the implementation and organisation/admin

It has now become clear that the land owners have a budget for this project, and they want us to submit a proposal so that they can see how much money is required.

Miscellaneous





Climate Change
Summers will be hotter, winters will be milder and with more rainfall.
Extreme weather conditions will become more frequent.

Sea level rises should not cause flooding

People
As this is a prospective design, we don't currently have any people to ask questions, although I did ask the site manager about any flooding.
It would be good to do some local consultation at some stage, if we get the go ahead to create this garden

The site is on private land with security gates and at present there is no access to the public. This may change, depending on what happens to the site.

The hall is a Grade II listed building. The walls of the walled garden are included in this. They have fallen into disrepair but will be refurbished in 2022

entry.content:

Overview

 

Aim

To decide how to present my diploma to make it effective, accessible and engaging

Date

28.10.21

Location

UK

Client

Myself

Status

Ongoing

Principles

Strategic

Framework

G.O.B.R.A.D.I.M.E. Goals, Observation, Boundaries, Resources, Analysis, Design, Implementation, Maintenance & Evaluation

This is a framework that was created by Heather Jo Flores. I'm using this because I haven't used it before.

Tools

Client interview, SMART goals, strengths and weaknesses analysis.

Resources/support

Killian's web design skills, other apprentice's websites for inspiration, Miro, Google Forms, Word, PowerPoint.

Context

This is a design about how I'm presenting my diploma portfolio for assessment and for a wider audience.

Having had some trouble presenting designs to people in the past, and this having quite serious consequences for the projects, I want to make sure that my designs are communicable to as many people as possible. This design will help me decide what format to use and how to approach it. I have now booked my assessment dates for my portfolio (the IPA and FPA), and this made me realise that I needed to think carefully about how to present this body of work. 

I enjoy looking at other diploma students' design portfolios and I would like to share my own, but would only be happy to do so if my work was of a standard that I was happy with, in  a format that I'm happy with.

Goals

I used SMART goals to pinpoint what I wanted. I created this with a Miro template.

I need to fix a couple of errors on this

Observation

I used a tool called Client Interview to find out what I was wanting to get out of my portfolio design. Yes, I interviewed myself.

Boundaries

Time is a boundary, I don't have time to be faffing - I just need a simple format that each design fits into for presentation. 

The fact that the designs need to be clear and concise, accessible and engaging is a boundary, because it means that I can't ramble. I need to be careful that I don't drift off subject. 

I don't want to spend a lot of money.

Resources

  • Access to the portfolios of numerous diploma students, via their websites
  • PowerPoint
  • Word
  • Excel
  • Miro
  • Body of work - designs in various stages of completion
  • My partner is a web site technician...

Analysis

I use Miro for a lot of my design work. It's an online whiteboard platform that is designed to allow teams to collaborate. Boards seem to be able to expand into infinity,  it's a very visual tool, and as my thinking is non-linear, it helps me to keep track of my ideas. I find it indispensable for designing. Because I love it so much, I wondered if I could use it to present my portfolio.

I did a strengths and weaknesses analysis to get a better picture. 

It was quite clear that a website would be better. I hadn't even considered that my partner could make me a website. That is how fixated I was on using Miro. If anyone wants to get me a Christmas/birthday present, subscription to Miro? Just sayin'...

Design Decisions

I will;

  • present my portfolio on a website
  • use different methods for creating content - including Miro, Word and PowerPoint, as well as others, but then each design will be displayed in same format on the website
  • continue working on designs and add them to the website when they're complete
  • write a website brief
  • set a writing style with rules

Implementation

Task When
Give Killian the brief  29.10.21
Killian to set up website   07.11.21
As I complete a design I will gather together all elements from on Miro/Word/PowerPoint etc and create pages on website  as and when
Add designs to website when they are ready - one a week until IPA then as and when until FPA (timeline also in ALP) as and when
Publish Website once first design goes up, so that my tutor can see it  07.11.21

Maintenance

As the site is static it requires less maintenance.

By uploading designs according to the timeline in my ALP, I will be maintaining the website regularly.

Technical changes may need to be made to keep website secure and functioning efficiently on modern browsers.

May need to update in line with legal compliance, e.g GDPR, cookies etc.

Evaluation

Have I met my goals?
1. Work out how to present my diploma
Yes, I have definitely done this. I have a template for the presentation of each of my designs. The design process worked well to meet this goal as it helped me to see things from different perspectives. It meets my long and short term needs because I now have a website to present my portfolio and I can add a section for my gardening business. I didn't quite keep to the deadline but I'm still pleased with the turnaround.  As you can see, the website is up and running!

I wanted to have a low carbon website. One option for this was to go with a low carbon website company. However, website designers aim to create a fast, efficient websites to  achieve high performance. Low carbon is a by-product of this. For this reason, I feel that I have met my goal. 

2. Do a speedy design
I had given myself a day to complete it, and I did whizz through it, but I had to go back and do a lot of tweaking because I'd missed stuff out. Even though I missed my deadline, it served my need to get a design done quickly, to progress the project. It helped me keep focussed and concise. 

3. Make it visually engaging
I will have to wait for feedback, but personally, I like it! 

4. Allow anyone to understand my designs
Again, I will have to wait until I get some feedback

Insert charts created with Google Forms.

Feedback so far:

wooof wooof woof, woof wooof. Woof woof woooof.

- Benji, Jessie's dog

Permaculture Principles


Strategic Principles

Feed what you want to grow 

I would like permaculture to grow - hopefully my website will help people to understand what it is, and inspire them to incorporate it into their own lives.

Eventually, I want to grow the website into a platform for my business, so I'm creating something that will serve my short term and long term goals.

I also really love techy stuff, and this design process will increase my skill set. 

Use edges

People looking for garden design will also see my permaculture designs, and therefore may learn something about permaculture and want to know more, perhaps even have it used in their gardens.

Make it beautiful

I intend to create a visually pleasing and cohesive website. 

Use onsite resources

Killian! I hadn't thought of enlisting his help, as I usually enjoy building websites myself, but as he offered and I'm short of time, I decided to run with it.


Work Where it Counts 

Rather than creating a second-rate presentation on Miro, developing the website idea is putting energy where it is most beneficial, and most accessible.


Invest Wisely

I am investing money into my website, but it is a sound investment as it will also support my business in the future. I am also using my time wisely, because trying to make Miro be something it isn't actually designed for would be a lot of work.

Be Realistic

Trying to get Miro to do everything was unrealistic, and also, I need to be realistic about how much time and energy I have for doing this work

Ethics

People Care

Self care; I'm making my diploma journey smoother by creating a well-thought out presentation process, This should mean that I experience as little stress as possible in the run up to completing my portfolio

Earth Care

I intend to have a website that has a low carbon footprint

Fair Share

Sharing designs with people online, widening the understanding of Permaculture

Reflection on the design process

What went well?

I genuinely had not considered getting Killian to set up a website for me, even though it may have been obvious to anyone else. Through the process I let go of my fixation with Miro, and with my need to do everything and conceded that I ought to let him help me!

I'm really pleased with the website, I'm confident that it has met my needs.

Also, Killian found a way to do it all for free, without adverts! 

What was challenging?

Choosing the right tools and understanding which elements of the design process fitted into which design step. Analysis still confuses me.

I did a SWOC analysis but it didn't work, it was too basic a concept so I just did a strengths and weaknesses analysis instead, which was appropriate to the task. That was really useful to see, I am starting to see how the finding the right tool for the right task is important.

Long term vision and goals

I hope to have my full portfolio of ten designs uploaded onto the website in time for my final assessment, which is on the twenty-second of February. 

At that stage, I can begin to develop the website in order to promote my gardening business and to present the design work that I will do after the accreditation. 

I would like to help other diploma students with their web sites, and by that I mean get Killian to help them with their websites!

Next achievable steps

Get feedback about the site and complete the evaluation

Share with my tutor for my first assessment

I hope to have five of my designs completed and uploaded onto the website in time for my interim portfolio assessment, the deadline for this is the first of December, 2021.

entry.title: Hello!
entry.content:
Welcome to my design portfolio for the Diploma in Applied Permaculture Design

 

“When you are a Bear of Very Little Brain, and you Think of Things, you find sometimes that a Thing which seemed very Thingish inside you is quite different when it gets out into the open and has other people looking at it.”
― A.A. Milne, Winnie-the-Pooh

So here you are in the place where I have put some Things that were very Thingish inside me. Well, hurrah, they are now out in the open for you to look at. I hope you like them. 

If you feel like letting me know what you think of my new website, you could fill in this form here. That would be very helpful and I will be hugely grateful.
